headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: New False Claim by Santos; Crypto Mining Wreaks Havoc on Towns; New Study on Losing Weight. Aired 6:30-7a ET

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy. Well, we're going to speak with that veteran straight ahead about that dog issue. No laughing matter, by the way.But this morning it appears George Santos has been caught in yet another lie. He has claimed, right, that his mother was in the south tower on 9/11. That has been reported for a while. Even, you know, it's on his campaign website. Here's the problem. Immigration records apparently show that that is not actually the case. She wasn't even in the U.S. On a 2003 form seen by CNN, the mother indicated that she hadn't been to America since 1999. She also filed paperwork in Brazil in 2001, just months before 9/11, saying that her Green Card had been stolen. It's in addition to, really, a long list of lies from the newly elected congressman. So, let's discuss now. CNN political commentators Scott Jennings and Alyssa Farah Griffin. They are both here. I'm sure they don't want to get close to this issue with a ten - with a ten foot pole.

utterances.speaker: ALYSSA FARAH GRIFFIN, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: Don't want to touch this.

utterances.speaker: SCOTT JENNINGS, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: No. No.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: There - there's one universal -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Good morning.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Good morning.One universal rule of politics, you don't mess with veterans and dogs. Actually, just life. And he managed to do both of those things.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK. We want to talk about that, but let's talk about the mom issue. What do you make of these - because it shows that his mother was not, apparently, in the World Trade Center on September 11th. That's pretty serious. A serious time for our - serious incident for our country and the world. And then -

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Well, and, I think, broadly it speaks to his character. I mean if you're lying about, you know, your mom's life, he's also apparently lied about the time that she's died through various tweets that have been resurfaced. He's a dishonest person. I'd say he's a bit of a con artist. But - well, he's like the gift that keeps giving in terms of like, it's kind of funny sometimes. It's very serious.From a national security perspective, this guy is ripe for adversaries to exploit. Like, Scott and I, when we were going into government, they - we go through the SF-86 (ph) process. They look into who you lived with. They talk to old roommates, all your old employers, to know that you're not somebody who could be blackmailed or subject to corruption. We don't do that with elected officials. It's a little bit different. The primary basically does that. And this is a person who is ripe to be a target for blackmail and exploitation. And now he's serving in Congress. And that's dangerous.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: This is a person totally unequipped to be there.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And it's - the thing is, its - so now he's lied about 9/11. He lied about the Holocaust. He lied about the Pulse nightclub shooting.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Jew-ish.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: He has lied about these really serious things.And I think the thing is, this is a consistent thing that he has said about his mother and 9/11. And he, as he's been caught in some of these lies, has removed some of them from his campaign website. But as of last night, this one about 9/11 was still on there.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: You ever meet people who like lie so much and so long about so many - they - they -- they begin to not be able to tell the difference from which --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's -- this guy I know named Scott Jennings. Sorry. Trump.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Go on.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: But, you know what I mean -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Like, you just get the impression that - that he has just lived his entire life as someone who makes things up to get through the next few moments. And - and if people seem to respond to it, then he uses it. And if they don't, he picks another thing. And so it's - it's quite troubling.I mean I - I still think to get rid of him out of the - by the way, if you talk to House Republicans, nobody wants to associate with this guy. They treat him like a pariah. I think to get rid of him it would be good -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Do they, though?

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: If - I - (INAUDIBLE) anyway.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: He just got -- he was just put on a committee. Two committees.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I don't know - I don't if he believes that.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Sure, but -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I have sources that don't think that he believes that's true.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: How would he know? I mean how would he know what's a terrible committee? I mean they stuck him off in the corner. A committee, the Ethics Committee, these prosecutors, these people that are looking into him, to me, I think the minute somebody comes back and says, yes, we've sort of validated all these accusations and we can now document without question either he has campaign finance problems or, you know, whatever it happens to be, that will be the trigger for them.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But won't it go from - excuse me - won't it go from a four person majority to a three person majority, which is something that Kevin McCarthy doesn't need. Probably why they're sticking with him right now. The main reason that they're sticking with him right now.I just want ask, you've worked in government too.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But you are -- you have been a strategist, right?

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And an adviser. What would your advice be to Kevin McCarthy right now and to Republicans in Washington as it relates to George Santos?

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Two - two-part plan. One, essentially put him in time out, which I think they've - they've basically done. And, two, they really do need to support the Ethics Committee moving as quickly as possible to document this person's problems so that they can then use that as the underpinning to toss him out.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You would get - you would say get rid of him?

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. I mean if the Ethics Committee says you've lied, and, by the way, you may have broken all these different laws on your campaign finance paperwork, absolutely. Toss him.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Even at this point?

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Well, and going a step further, too, if I were Kevin McCarthy, I would be actively recruiting in that district for who another credible Republican is that could run if this is something that comes to a resignation and goes to a special election. It's obviously a D plus one district. Biden carried it. So, he's worried about what's going to - what would be a difficult uphill battle.But this guy won it. It's not that a Republican can't win it. Be looking for who that, you know, moderate business man or woman is and try to get them ready to go if that comes to it.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Yes, if they don't move on him, I mean, look, they're going to toss him out in the primary next year anyway, those voters are. I mean this guy's not going to be in Congress, you know -- at a maximum he's going to be in Congress for two years.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That's two years that his constituents have this guy representing them.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. JENNINGS

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Alyssa, I want to ask you about something else, though, because we also were looking at what the former president was arguing yesterday. And I covered his classified documents thing very closely, but it struck out to me what he is now talking about, which are the empty folders that the FBI found when they searched Mar-a-Lago. I think it was close to 50 of them, 48 of them. And now he's zeroing in on this saying that they were just a cool keepsake he kept from Oval Office meetings where they'd come in with classified documents in the folds. He would keep just the folder and they would take the documents. Is that ever something you saw happen when you were in the White House?

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: No. And it would be kind of a bizarre thing to do. The whole purpose of the cover sheet is that it covers the classified information. So, a CIA briefer, when they take it back, would in all likelihood keep that document. I would assume that if you have a cover sheet that that meant that you had classified information under it. That seems like a weird line of (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Typically in a briefing, if someone gave the president a classified document with a folder, they would take back both, including the folder?

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. That's what's kind of odd about both the Biden and the Trump cases is, you really do have somebody come and present it to you, brief it, talk you through it, and then take it back. For the president to just even be kind of holding and collecting in a drawer classified documents isn't even really standard. And if you keep it in your office, it should be in a lock box. The Oval Office is a SCIF, but because you do have foot traffic in and out of it, you - you still would have to have it in a lock box. And it doesn't really make sense to me why you would - why he's leaning into the cover sheets.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: The president, also, I think, said in his statement that if -- he has the folders, but if there were any documents they were probably planted there by the -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: By the gestapo, which is now his new name for the FBI.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Which is - which is sort of what the fever swaps of the left are saying about the Biden documents. Well, you know, the Republicans must have put them in his garage. And so I found that to be the most curious part of this statement is that you have accusations of planting. They did -- none of these things were planted. Let's just - I mean, come on.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But, I mean, what do you make of a former Republican president outwardly referring to the FBI as the gestapo. Not saying they're gestapo like, not saying some of them are, he is outwardly calling them the gestapo.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Terrible. Awful.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Going to be the first - your first question at the beginning of this, you ever heard - met someone or heard someone who can't believe - I mean, look, he learned from the best, right? This guy learned from - this is "The New York Post" saying, this is sort of my gauge, right, that "The New York Post" now does not like Trump, right? And they don't apparently like Santos because they're saying Santos is too big a liar even for politics.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Not - not -- they didn't even bring up the, what is it, Qatara (ph) - Qatara (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Yes, we now know that he performed in drag in Brazil, which, more power to him.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Allegedly.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Allegedly. If he wants to. But that will be interesting to see how that fits into his new friends in the Freedom Caucus who have kind of declared a war on drag.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And just the one thing I would say there is I think Trump lowered the standard so much for character and integrity in politics, and George Santos is a direct result of that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Good to see you. Early for you. Are you awake?

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Am I not performing up to your high standards here?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: No. Do you miss fighting with me at night?

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I was just telling my wife the other day that I really miss 11

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Can I let you in on a little secret? I don't miss it.By the way, I have a story for Scott.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I have a story for you coming up. We're going to talk about intermittent fasting, which you got me on intermittent fasting. I lost 30 pounds because - in large part because of you.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: It works. It works.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: In small part - yes, well, I don't know. They think. Maybe. We'll let you know.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, Alyssa, Scott --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: They're telling us we've got to go.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Kaitlan's moving us along.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Thank you both so much.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, guys.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, a different kind of mining is bringing a different kind of pollution to one of the most peaceful spots in North Carolina. Bill Weir spoke to homeowners who are now haunted by the hum of these large fans.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: When it's at about 75, 80 decibels, id' say a jet engine. A jet engine that never leaves.(END VIDEO CLIP) (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Look, you may be involved in this because there's more than 20 million people from the Midwest to the Great Lakes under winter storm threats. Some areas expecting to see up to 17 inches of snow today. You're looking live at Denver, which recorded the largest snowfall in January in 30 years. More than 9 inches as of Wednesday evening. It is the eighth largest two-day snowfall for this month. I'll say that again, the eighth largest two-day snowfall for this month. I want you to take a look at some of the snowfall totals. More than 23 inches in Merna, Nebraska, more than 17 inches in Litchfield, Nebraska, 11 inches in Aurora, Arizona. This storm is expected to move east today.

utterances.speaker: BILL WEIR, CNN CHIEF CLIMATE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, it's -- the volume goes from maybe 55 to 80 decibels in the guy's yard next door to the mine. But it's not the volume, it's the constant. This thing turned on in September '21 and it's not shut off, which is -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Not at night. Not on weekends. Nothing. WEIRThese are retirees, long-time landowners there. And they'd heard about crypto and thought, ah, maybe it's smoke and mirrors. Maybe some invested. But then they heard the sound of crypto and it changes everything in this county. Take a look. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) WEIR (voice over): This is the sound of Green Mountain Farm. Certified by Quiet Parks International as one of the most peaceful spots in North Carolina. Thanks to their rare local enforcement of laws against noise pollution. Meanwhile, about 90 minutes away, beautiful Cherokee County sounds like this. It is stack upon stack of computer servers, and the fans needed to cool them. This is what's known as a crypto mine. And it makes the sound of people in San Francisco trying to make virtual money. WEIR (on camera): How do you describe that noise?

utterances.speaker: MIKE LUGIEWICZ, MURPHY RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: We're probably sitting at probably 65 decibels right now. When it's at about 75, 80 decibels, I'd say a jet engine. A jet engine that never leaves.WEIR (voice over): Sixteen months after the mine fired up without warning, Mike Lugiewicz put his house up for sale in frustration. TOM LASH (ph), MURPHY RESIDENT: There would be turkeys out in the field and deer by the hundreds. WEIR (on camera): Yes.

utterances.speaker: LASH
utterances.sentences: You don't have that anymore.WEIR (voice over): While Tom Lash (ph) misses the wildlife.

utterances.speaker: PHYLLIS CANTRELL, MURPHY RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: You don't sleep at night.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Phyllis Cantrell says she feels trapped.

utterances.speaker: CANTRELL
utterances.sentences: You can actually lay your head on the pillow and hear it hum up through the walls.WEIR (on camera): No way. Have you thought about moving?

utterances.speaker: CANTRELL
utterances.sentences: We're 73 years old. Where are we going to go?

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Imagine a game where the dice have a billion sides and the first person to roll a ten wins. That is essentially crypto mining. And to play that games these days, you need computers, thousands of computers, running 24/7, 365.And after China outlawed crypto currency and crypto mining, more and more mines like this began popped up in Appalachia. Places where the power is cheap and the regulations are either nonexistent or unenforced.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Let's all pray.WEIR (voice over): But in this deep red Republican pocket --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: They've got noise 24/7. Noise and sound (INAUDIBLE) do nothing to help these people. What are you guys going to do to help?

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: The mine has upended local politics.

utterances.speaker: JUDY STINES, MURPHY RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: I like to be behind the scenes, and I - I like to stir the pot. And I knew that we -- we needed to win an election.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Forget the noise --

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Outrage over the mine helped flip the balance of power in November's county election.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) U.S. Senator Thom Tillis.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: With the new board of commissioners now asking for federal help in ending American crypto mining.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: To introduce and champion legislation through the U.S. Congress to ban, (INAUDIBLE) or regulate crypto mining operations in the United States of America. (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: When asked over LinkedIn for reaction, Chandler Song, one of the mine's co-owners wrote, oh, boy, they wanted us so bad a year ago.As for the proposed ban, it is unconstitutional to say the least. Song and his crypto mining co-founder made Forbes 30 under 30 list a few years ago and recently claimed quarterly revenues of more than $20 million. But when asked follow-up questions, Song went silent. His mine in Murphy has not, so far. But the county attorney is looking for a legal way to shut it down. A cautionary reminder that the next time you hear a place as peaceful as Green Mountain Farm --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You're playing roulette with their lives.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's torture.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Come on. WEIR(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It sounds like you're on a tarmac almost.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: It does.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: He was saying it's a jet engine that never leaves. It really does sound like you're out boarding a plane or something.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Right. And he's like, we've got a racetrack right over there. We hear them racing on Friday nights. It's awesome. But at least they stop and we can go to bed.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, Bill Weir, that's a fascinating piece. Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It is fascinating. Thank you both very much. Appreciate it.Which is a better way to lose weight, intermittent fasting or calorie cutting? Dr. Tara Narula has the stats. She's next. (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, if one of your New Year's resolutions was to lose weight, this might be of interest to you. A new study by the American Heart Association says a popular diet strategy of limiting food intake to a specific time window, which you may have heard your friends talk about this, it's called intermittent fasting, may not be an effective weight loss strategy.Joining us now to talk about this is our CNN medical correspondent and cardiologist, Dr. Tara Narula. OK, so I know a lot of people that do this. One of them may or may not be at this table. So, what are the -- DR. TARA NARULA, CNN MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT: It's not me.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: No, I'm not going to - look, I'm not going to -- never doubt science, right, or medicine.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But I know it works for me.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And I know it has worked for me. I know it has worked for a lot of people. Look, it may not be -- maybe the intermittent fasting. I think what it does is, it causes your stomach to shrink. You get used to not eating. And in the time that is allotted for you to eat, like I do 16/8.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: In that eight hours, I often find myself not being able to eat all of the calories that's allotted.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And so, therefore, I will lose weight. So, I think it teaches you discipline and I do think it sort of helps in restricting calories. So, it may not work in the way that people think it works, it's just intermittent fasting, but I think it's also helping to restrict the calories and it gives you a little bit more discipline. NARULAsays, yes, it works, some says it doesn't - some say it doesn't. A lot of the research has been done in animals and it's been sort of short term. So the question is, is this something sustainable over the long term. But, there are a couple different types of intermittent fasting programs. You do the 16/8, with that daily intermittent fasting, which is probably the most common. You restrict eating from say maybe 11:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. and then you have that 12, 18 hour period where you're not eating at all. Some people do alternate days. So they fast one day, eat the next day. And some do like a 5/2, where they eat five days and then not two. And there's some data suggests this helps the cells regenerate. It helps you go into a state of ketosis where you break down fat. So, there definitely may be something to it for sure.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I just want people to know you do eat sometimes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Lie McDonald's when you do eat. So, I don't want people to be worried about you.Doctor, thank you for sharing that with us.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, up next, we have new CNN reporting on President Biden's re-election run and what that looks like.
